front.title: The fp Link Format Attribute
front.keyword: CoAP, Link Format, resource discovery through Proxies

abstract.t: This memo proposes a new CoRE link format attribute, "fp", to be used by a Proxy node to inform CoAP endpoints that the associated resource can be reached through the Proxy itself.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The discovery mechanism described in assumes cheap and pervasive multicast. This may not always be the case due to either limitations in the underlying radio link (see Section 1 of ), or the absence of a multicast routing protocol to bridge through different links.

Given their topological role, CoAP Proxies (Section 5.7 of ) can be used efficiently to make resources discoverable across different broadcast domains. However, in order to achieve this capability, the fact that a given resource is made available through them must be made explicit to consuming endpoints, so that they can use the Proxy-Uri Option to dereference the final target.
This memo defines the "fp" CoAP link format attribute that can be used by Proxy nodes to inform CoAP endpoints that a given resource can be reached by passing through the advertising Proxy.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: The fp Link Format Attribute
section.t: Consider the scenario depicted in . Two separate CoAP links are proxied by P. Node A hosts resource /res of type "x", and P knows it -- either through explicit or implicit mechanism (e.g. previous discovery on the local link, or a co-located RD, etc.)

We would like to allow B to discover that A hosts a resource with type "x" even if A can't be directly reached by B. P may in principle let this information filter from one link to the other, but given the way discovery via /.well-known/core is currently defined (Section 2.1 of ), there is no way for a consuming node to determine that an advertised link is to be accessed through a forward Proxy.

We may decide use the anchor parameter in the link and define a new relation name to express the "proxied by" relation, but this may actually have zero chance to work because of the freedom left to a consuming node to ignore anchored links (Section 2.3 of ).

The proposed solution, instead, envisages a new link format attribute, "fp" that is added by the Proxy to the original set of attributes of the linked resource to inform the requesting endpoint that the advertised (absolute) URI must be requested to the advertising Proxy using the Proxy-URI Option, as illustrated in . When advertised on a link different from the one on which it resides, the original resource link SHALL be transformed by the Proxy into an absolute URI that can be used as-is in a Proxy-Uri Option by the requesting node.

figure.artwork: P B | | |<-----+ Uri-Path: .well-known | GET | Uri-Path: core | | | | +----->| Content-Type: link-format | 2.05 | payload: <coap://A/res>;rt="x";fp

section.t: Note that in case the "fp" attribute is present, the URI-Reference in the link-value MUST always be a URI and not a relative-ref .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The mechanism specified in this document shares the same security weakness of the discovery process described in .
Especially critical to the CoAP network consistency, is the fact that in NoSec mode a malicious attacker could poison the response of a query to the /.well-known/core in order to re-route traffic.
